clinical_study.brief_title: Spironolactone on Fibrosis Progrssion-Portal Hypertension(FP-PH)in Cirrhosis
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Spironolactone on Fibrosis Progression and Portal Hypertension in Patients With Compensated Cirrhosis

collaborator.agency: Nanfang Hospital of Southern Medical University

clinical_study.source: Shanghai Tongji Hospital, Tongji University School of Medicine

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of this study is to investigate the effects of spironolactone on liver fibrosis progression and portal hypertension in patients with compensated cirrhosis. The patients were nonrandomized according to the medical conditions determined by the physicians, in 3 arms (spironolactone start from 40mg once daily and increase every week with a maximum dose as 100mg once daily, carvedilol start from 6.25mg once daily and increase to 12.5mg once daily in next week if being tolerated, spironolactone in combination with carvedilol: spironolactone is added when carvedilol has reached the most tolerated dose). Portal pressure gradient by virtual hepatic venous pressure gradients based on enhanced CT, and liver elasticity by Fibroscan Medical Device are documented at baseline level and every six months after the treatment. Changes in serum fibrosis markers and liver function are monitored before and every 3 months after the treatment.

primary_outcome.measure: liver elasticity as assessed by Fibroscan

secondary_outcome.measure: Portal pressure gradient(PPG) as determined by a virtual PPG (vPPG) based on CT angiography and Doppler ultrasound
incidence rate of cirrhosis-related complications as recorded in patient history

intervention.description: spironolactone starts from 40mg once daily and increase every week with a maximum dose as 100mg once daily
carvedilol starts from 6.25mg once daily and increase to 12.5mg once daily in next week if being tolerated
spironolactone is added when carvedilol has reached the most tolerated dose

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Proven compensated cirrhosis based on histology or unequivocal clinical, sonographic and laboratory findings
- Proven portal hypertension by calculated virtual HVPG >12mmHg based on enhanced CT
- Child-Pugh score < 9
- Suspension of alcohol intake for at least 6 weeks before enrollment
Exclusion Criteria:
- Treatment with angiotensin II receptor antagonists or angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors in the last 2 months
- Renal insufficiency
- Hepatic encephalopathy at stage 2
- Contraindications to beta-blockers or spironolactone.
- Other organ fibrosis situations
- Malignant diseases
- Portal vein thrombosis
